thread.title: Vanity Fair Pulls Out of White House Correspondents’ Dinner After-Party
thread.title_full: Vanity Fair Pulls Out of White House Correspondents’ Dinner After-Party - WSJ

author: Lukas I. Alpert
title: Vanity Fair Pulls Out of White House Correspondents’ Dinner After-Party

organizations.name: vanity fair pulls out of white house

text:
8 COMMENTS Vanity Fair, whose editor Graydon Carter has feuded with Donald Trump over the years, has decided to pull out of the White House Correspondents’ Dinner after-party it has co-hosted with Bloomberg LP since 2009, according to a spokeswoman for the magazine.
The after-party will still go on, just hosted by Bloomberg alone, a person familiar with the situation said, but Mr. Carter and the Vanity Fair crew will stay home. The two companies had hosted the party together since the beginning of the Obama administration.
It is one of Washington’s high-profile affairs and follows the annual event when the president tells jokes before a crowd of journalists and celebrities.
There had been some doubt that the main event would be held at all, given the Trump administration’s battles with the White House press corps since taking office. Mr. Trump’s chief strategist, Steve Bannon, referred to the media in a recent New York Times article as an “opposition party,” that ought to “keep its mouth shut.”
But on Thursday, the White House Correspondents’ Association confirmed its annual black-tie gala is on for April 29 at the Washington Hilton.
The New Yorker, which like Vanity Fair is published by Conde Nast, has also decided not to host its annual correspondent’s dinner pre-party, a spokeswoman for the magazine said. The New York Times earlier reported on the New Yorker’s decision .
Late-night show host Samantha Bee has already announced plans for a counter-party, a “Not the White House Correspondents’ Dinner” event with proceeds to go to the Committee to Protect Journalists.
The long-running feud between Messrs. Trump and Carter dates back to the 1980s, when Mr. Carter helped immortalize the real estate tycoon – by then already well-known on the New York scene – as a “short-fingered vulgarian” in the pages of the now-defunct Spy magazine.
When Mr. Trump several times on the campaign trail made pointed reference to the size of his hands, some saw echoes of the fight with Mr. Carter.
The enmity hasn’t cooled now that Mr. Trump has taken office, with him recently dismissing Mr. Carter as a “no talent” hack in response to a scathing Vanity Fair review of a Trump Tower restaurant.
Still, Mr. Trump has appeared in the pages and on the cover of Vanity Fair in the past, and he and wife Melania have attended the magazine’s annual Oscar party several times.
The magazine was a harsh critic of the president during the election, with Mr. Carter writing several searing pieces on Mr. Trump in which he accused him of trafficking in bigotry and declaring that he would “leave a permanent orange stain” on American politics even if he had lost.
Mr. Trump hasn’t pulled his punches with the magazine chieftain over the years, referring to him as “Dopey Graydon Carter” on Twitter and claiming his restaurant, the Waverly Inn, has “the worst food” in New York.
—Joe Flint contributed to this article.
Write to Lukas I. Alpert at lukas.alpert@wsj.com and Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg at jeffrey.trachtenberg@wsj.com
